rev.diff:
Line 27: Line 27:
'''Mokgadi Caster Semenya''' (born 7 January 1991) is a [[South Africa]]n [[middle-distance runner]] and world champion.<ref name="Birth certificate backs SA gender">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8215112.stm|title= Birth certificate backs SA gender |date=21 August 2009|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=21 August 2009}}</ref><ref name=Times/> Semenya won gold in the women's [[800 metres]] at the [[2009 World Championships in Athletics|2009 World Championships]] with a [[800 metres#Women's Seasons Best (Outdoor)|time of 1:55.45]] in the final.
'''Mokgadi Caster Semenya''' (born 7 January 1991) is a [[South Africa]]n [[middle-distance runner]] and world champion.<ref name="Birth certificate backs SA gender">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8215112.stm|title= Birth certificate backs SA gender |date=21 August 2009|publisher=BBC News |accessdate=21 August 2009}}</ref><ref name=Times/> Semenya won gold in the women's [[800 metres]] at the [[2009 World Championships in Athletics|2009 World Championships]] with a [[800 metres#Women's Seasons Best (Outdoor)|time of 1:55.45]] in the final.
â
+
<!-- There is consensus, per policy that Caster Semenya should be referred to by the feminine pronoun (she/her). Please DO NOT change this without reading the reasons and if you still feel it is warranted, discussing on talk page first-->
â
Following it's victory at the 2009 World Championships, questions were raised about whether Semenya had a physical condition that might give it an unfair advantage over other female racers.<ref name=Times>{{cite news |url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/athletics/article6802314.ece |title=Caster Semenya faces sex test before it can claim victory |publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=19 August 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2009 | location=London | first=Owen | last=Slot}}</ref> It was withdrawn from international competition until 6 July 2010 when the IAAF cleared her to return to competition.<ref name=ReturnTrack>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hMudI8ByYmbiNVB4ofKjep_IT_kQD9GPJLSO0|title=Semenya cleared to return to track immediately|accessdate=6 July 2010|publisher=Associated Press|date=6 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2010/jul/06/caster-semenya-iaaf-clearance|title=Caster Semenya may return to track this month after IAAF clearance|accessdate=6 July 2010|publisher=The Guardian|date=6 July 2010 | location=London | first=Anna | last=Kessel}}</ref> In 2010, the British magazine [[New Statesman]] included Semenya in its list "The World's 50 Most Influential Figures 2010".<ref name="htanna">{{cite web|title=Caster Semenya - 50 people that matter 2010|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/2010/09/intersex-symbol-caster-semenya|accessdate=15 October 2010}}</ref>
+
Following her victory at the 2009 World Championships, questions were raised about whether Semenya had a physical condition that might give her an unfair advantage over other female racers.<ref name=Times>{{cite news |url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/more_sport/athletics/article6802314.ece |title=Caster Semenya faces sex test before she can claim victory |publisher=''[[The Times]]''|date=19 August 2009 |accessdate=20 August 2009 | location=London | first=Owen | last=Slot}}</ref> She was withdrawn from international competition until 6 July 2010 when the IAAF cleared her to return to competition.<ref name=ReturnTrack>{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5hMudI8ByYmbiNVB4ofKjep_IT_kQD9GPJLSO0|title=Semenya cleared to return to track immediately|accessdate=6 July 2010|publisher=Associated Press|date=6 July 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/sport/2010/jul/06/caster-semenya-iaaf-clearance|title=Caster Semenya may return to track this month after IAAF clearance|accessdate=6 July 2010|publisher=The Guardian|date=6 July 2010 | location=London | first=Anna | last=Kessel}}</ref> In 2010, the British magazine [[New Statesman]] included Semenya in its list "The World's 50 Most Influential Figures 2010".<ref name="htanna">{{cite web|title=Caster Semenya - 50 people that matter 2010|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/2010/09/intersex-symbol-caster-semenya|accessdate=15 October 2010}}</ref>
==Early life and education==
==Early life and education==
â
Semenya was born in Ga-Masehlong, a village in [[South Africa]] near [[Polokwane]], and grew up in the village of Fairlie, "deep in South Africa's northern [[Limpopo]] province."<ref name="Birth certificate backs SA gender"/><ref name=Mail/> She has three sisters and a brother, and her family are members of the [[Zion Christian Church]].<ref name=Mail>{{cite web|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1208227/It-wouldnt-wear-dresses-sounds-like-man-phone-Caster-Semenyas-father-sex-riddle-daughter.html |title= 'She wouldn't wear dresses and sounds like a man on the phone': Caster Semenya's father on his sex-riddle daughter |date=23 August 2009|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]'' |accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> She is said to have been a [[tomboy]] as a child.<ref name=Mail/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universalsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=23000&ATCLID=204778766|title=Caster Semenya's present and future|last=Abrahamson|first=Alan|date=20 August 2009|publisher=[[Universal Sports]]|accessdate=30 August 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
+
Semenya was born in Ga-Masehlong, a village in [[South Africa]] near [[Polokwane]], and grew up in the village of Fairlie, "deep in South Africa's northern [[Limpopo]] province."<ref name="Birth certificate backs SA gender"/><ref name=Mail/> She has three sisters and a brother, and her family are members of the [[Zion Christian Church]].<ref name=Mail>{{cite web|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/worldnews/article-1208227/She-wouldnt-wear-dresses-sounds-like-man-phone-Caster-Semenyas-father-sex-riddle-daughter.html |title= 'She wouldn't wear dresses and sounds like a man on the phone': Caster Semenya's father on his sex-riddle daughter |date=23 August 2009|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]'' |accessdate=27 August 2009}}</ref> She is said to have been a [[tomboy]] as a child.<ref name=Mail/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.universalsports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=23000&ATCLID=204778766|title=Caster Semenya's present and future|last=Abrahamson|first=Alan|date=20 August 2009|publisher=[[Universal Sports]]|accessdate=30 August 2009}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
Semenya attended Nthema Secondary School and now attends [[Pretoria University]] as a first-year [[sports science]] student.<ref name=Times/><ref>[http://www.wistv.com/Global/story.asp?S=10963679 SAfrican in gender flap gets gold for 800 win] 22 August 2009, By RYAN LUCAS, Associated Press Writer</ref> She began running as training for [[association football|soccer]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=1057364 |title=Hero Casterâs road to gold|last=Prince |first=Chandre|date=29 August 2009|publisher=[[The Times]]|accessdate=30 August 2009}}</ref>
Semenya attended Nthema Secondary School and now attends [[Pretoria University]] as a first-year [[sports science]] student.<ref name=Times/><ref>[http://www.wistv.com/Global/story.asp?S=10963679 SAfrican in gender flap gets gold for 800 win] 22 August 2009, By RYAN LUCAS, Associated Press Writer</ref> She began running as training for [[association football|soccer]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.thetimes.co.za/News/Article.aspx?id=1057364 |title=Hero Casterâs road to gold|last=Prince |first=Chandre|date=29 August 2009|publisher=[[The Times]]|accessdate=30 August 2009}}</ref>
